author: Staff Reporter
text:
What if a ban on hen and rooster was introduced in an imaginary democratic country whose laws are similar to those in India?

That was the moot problem thrown at students of law.

In the end, the team from SASTRA School of Law, Thanjavur, emerged winners.

SASTRA reached finals

In the moot court competition organised by Madras Bar Association and N. Natarajan Charitable Trust, SASTRA School of Law, Thanjavur, and the School of Excellence in Law, Chennai, reached the finals, beating nine other teams on the way.

Naveen Kumar Murthi, a lawyer practising at Madras High Court, said they had plans to make it a national event next year.

Satish K. Agnihotri, Judge, Madras High Court, said money should not be the sole criterion in legal profession. “The focus should be on law. You should try your best to make sure you do not appear for a wrong cause,” he added.

U.U. Lalit, judge, Supreme Court of India, said while practising criminal law, the satisfaction one got when a lawyer represented an innocent person to get reprieve for him or her was immense.

Awards for best researcher and speaker and memorial awards were distributed.

Madras Bar Association plans

to make it a national event

next year
title: Moot court contest held
